channel.title: Nitpicky optimization help
channel.description:
Hey, I'm trying to optimize code and I came across a time where I find: [code]float val = shortValue / (floatValue1 * floatValue2);[/code] [size=11px][font=monaco]I've seen people change that to:[/font][/size] [code]float reciprocalVal = 1 / (floatValue1 * floatValue2); float val = shortValue * reciprocalVal;[/code]
[size=11px][font=monaco]The latter looks like it does more math, yet, like I said before, I've seen people change it to the above in order to optimize.[/font][/size]
[size=11px][font=monaco]Which is better?[/font][/size]
[font=monaco][size=11px]Edit: I'm not sure if this helps but with the first choice I got 62 fps average and on the second I got 60[/size][/font]

item.title: Nitpicky optimization help
item.dc:creator: @Docent Limits
item.description:
@Docent wrote:

[quote=“Tree, post:16, topic:548673”][quote author=Limits link=topic=667580.msg4464716#msg4464716 date=1419383872]

JVisualVM is an alright tool that comes standard with JDK

Edit: Wow, holy cow I had no idea that this program was out there already, that helped so much. Thanks.
[/quote]

If you shut up for once and stopped vomiting your rubbish all over these boards, you may even continue to learn something.
Fingers crossed.[/quote]
Or you can go to hell and this will all smooth over, Dr. Pessemistic…

Read full topic

item.title: Nitpicky optimization help
item.dc:creator: @Docent Limits
item.description:
@Docent wrote:

[quote=“object, post:12, topic:548673”]The reciprocal is the multiplicative inverse of a number.

Because multiplication is faster than division, and you have the opportunity to pre-calculate the reciprocal of the number that you want to divide with, you can save some computation time by multiplying with that pre-calculated reciprocal instead. The result is the same. I use it all the time in my 3D software renderers.

Although, there are places where you shouldn’t use it. Simply because you wouldn’t save anything doing so. If you divide a number once, and you don’t have an opportunity to pre-calculate the reciprocal as a constant field, you would have to perform more computations than if you just divided it in the first place.

On the other hand, multiplying with the reciprocal makes the code harder to understand for people that are not used to it. Take yourself as an example. And, in a lot of cases there would really be no difference. So having it just because, well, that’s up to you to decide, but it’s not necessary.

As others have said, premature optimization isn’t the way to go. First, make it work. Then, if you’re not satisfied with the FPS as in your case, profile your application and try to find bottlenecks in your code. If you change your code based on what you think is an optimization, and it isn’t, change it back. Even though it makes no difference performance-wize, unless of course the “optimization” makes the code more clear. Having clear code weights more than having code with “optimizations” that really makes no difference.[/quote]
Thank you for such an in-depth answer. How do you suggest profiling your code?

Read full topic

item.title: Nitpicky optimization help
item.dc:creator: @Protosstribe object
item.description:
@Protosstribe wrote:

The reciprocal is the multiplicative inverse of a number.

Because multiplication is faster than division, and you have the opportunity to pre-calculate the reciprocal of the number that you want to divide with, you can save some computation time by multiplying with that pre-calculated reciprocal instead. The result is the same. I use it all the time in my 3D software renderers.

Although, there are places where you shouldn’t use it. Simply because you wouldn’t save anything doing so. If you divide a number once, and you don’t have an opportunity to pre-calculate the reciprocal as a constant field, you would have to perform more computations than if you just divided it in the first place.

On the other hand, multiplying with the reciprocal makes the code harder to understand for people that are not used to it. Take yourself as an example. And, in a lot of cases there would really be no difference. So having it just because, well, that’s up to you to decide, but it’s not necessary.

As others have said, premature optimization isn’t the way to go. First, make it work. Then, if you’re not satisfied with the FPS as in your case, profile your application and try to find bottlenecks in your code. If you change your code based on what you think is an optimization, and it isn’t, change it back. Even though it makes no difference performance-wize, unless of course the “optimization” makes the code more clear. Having clear code weights more than having code with “optimizations” that really makes no difference.

Read full topic

item.title: Nitpicky optimization help
item.dc:creator: @Docent Limits
item.description:
@Docent wrote:

[quote=“AtomicInt_, post:10, topic:548673”]That isn’t the same as the code you provided,

float den = 1 / r;
sum += a * den;
sum += b * den;

This performs 3 different operations get, increment and store, assuming [tt]r[/tt] isn’t constant it cannot be folded.[/quote]
I guess you’re right, I should worry about this too much.

Read full topic

item.title: Nitpicky optimization help
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

That isn’t the same as the code you provided,

float den = 1 / r;
sum += a * den;
sum += b * den;

This performs 3 different operations get, increment and store, assuming [tt]r[/tt] isn’t constant it cannot be folded.

I guess it’s my fault for assuming your case was using constant values… oops

Read full topic

item.title: Nitpicky optimization help
item.dc:creator: @Docent Limits
item.description:
@Docent wrote:

[quote=“AtomicInt_, post:6, topic:548673”]http://c2.com/cgi/wiki?PrematureOptimization

All optimization is premature unless:
- Your application is too slow
- You have profiled your code and it shows an optimization would improve things
- You are optimizing for memory

In your example it is totally premature, the compiler folds the arithmetic down anyways[/quote]
http://highperformanceinjava.blogspot.com/2013/02ision-vs-multiplication.html

What’s this?

Read full topic

item.title: Nitpicky optimization help
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

http://c2.com/cgi/wiki?PrematureOptimization

All optimization is premature unless:
- Your application is too slow
- You have profiled your code and it shows an optimization would improve things
- You are optimizing for memory

In your example it is totally premature, the compiler folds the arithmetic down anyways

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

Stop… premature optimization is the root of all evil.

Forget about the small efficiencies. The compiler will inline that operation anyway.
